reviewText: Director Steven Spielberg and actor Tom Hanks pair up for a these two attempts at light comedy.  Now the idea that Spielberg and Hanks, who worked together on "Saving Private Ryan," would spend there time on this trifle might be too much for some fans to take. But then Leonardo DiCaprio, who had seen little sign of the critical success ("What's Eating Gilbert Grape") or box office success ("Titanic") of his earlier days was probably just happy to have had movies with Spielberg and Martin Scorsese out at the same time. Okay, so "Catch Me If You Can" is not a great film. It is a very good film and that puts all the parties concerned ahead of the game given the standard fare from Hollywood.The story might not be about life and death, but it is certainly compelling. Young Frank W. Abagnale Jr (DiCaprio) runs away from home rather than deal with the divorce of his parents and has to live by his wits and the checkbook in his back pocket. It turns out his wits are pretty good and he is not only able to pass millions of dollars worth of bad checks, but pass himself off as an airline pilot, doctor, and lawyer. Doggedly pursuing him is F.B.I. agent Carl Hanratty (Hanks), who knows that Frank is really a beggarman and thief. Actually, we know that Frank will get his man, because that is how the film opens, and it is as Hanratty is bringing Frank back to the United States from France that the story is revealed."Catch Me If You Can," based on Abagnale's biography, is the story of an engaging rogue who uses his charm and aforementioned quick wits to get himself out of one sticky situation after another. The man had panache, which is exemplified when he has to get through the Miami airport despite the fact Hanratty has F.B.I. agents at every other line. The movie is not really a primer for a life of crime since Abagnale's did his con man act in the Sixties and technology has advanced well beyond his effective use of a bathtub full of water and model airplanes to make thousands of dollars.In addition to the questions regarding how Frank does it and how Hanratty catches him, there is the relationship between the two men as well as the relationship between Frank and his father (Christopher Walken), from whom he gets his charm and sense of larceny. It is when the film operates on this level that "Catch Me If You Can" becomes another classic Spielberg film, at least in the sense of the constant theme of symbolic fathers and sons, even if it never gets churned into real butter."The Terminal" is certainly based on a contrived situation, but there is nothing wrong with that being the case. Viktor Navorski (Tom Hanks) arrived in the United States at JFK Airport in New York City, clutching a bag and a can of Planter's Peanuts. Unfortunately while his plane was flying across the Atlantic there was a military coup in his native land of Krakozia. According to the bureaucrats his nation no longer exists, which means his passport is no longer valid, his visa has been rejected, and he cannot be allowed to enter the United States (that is, to go outside the airport). He cannot be allowed to return back to his warn torn country. To add insult to injury, when Customs official Frank Dixon (Stanley Tucci) tries to explain to Navorski why he is "unacceptable," the poor guy does not understand enough English to really understand what is happening to him.Yes, you can certainly reach a translator on the phone if you do not have one on hand and the government has regulations for what happens in situations like this that do not allow people to fall through the cracks. But if we can entertain a willing suspension of disbelief to watch movies about catastrophic climatic changes and teenagers given mutant powers by the bite of a radioactive spider we can enjoy Steven Spielberg's fable about a man stuck in an airport terminal and refusing to lose his optimism or his humanity. Besides, there really was somebody who was forced to stay in an airport terminal, an Iranian refugee whose his passport and United Nations refugee certificate had been stolen (it was Charles De Gaulle Airport and French officials who refused to let the man go anywhere).Hanks, looking rather frumpy, provides another performance that shows he is at his best as a leading man when he is proving himself to be a character actor. Some of his most effective moments are when he is speaking in his foreign tongue, where the words are never understood but the emotional meanings are always clear. He plays a character that is told he cannot leave the airport terminal and so he does not leave the airport terminal. As he goes through the routines of his holding pattern keep encountering a small cast of characters including Gupta Rajan (Kumar Pallana), the janitor who likes to mop floors and watch people ignore the signs and fall on their butts, and Amelia (Catherine Zeta-Jones), the flight attendant who loses a heel on her shoe in front of Navorski doing just that. Meanwhile our hero has to deal with just surviving living in an airport terminal. Of course he does more than that, and as you would imagine he becomes something of a cult hero to those who work in the terminal as he not only endures but also perseveres.Remember that this story is not a linear narrative but one that circles around, sometimes going down and sometimes up.  You will also fall into the traps of various expectations with regards to the villain and the beautiful girl of the piece. But neither Dixon nor Amelia fits the stereotype and these somewhat rude awakenings serve to remind us that this film is about something else. That is because the biggest case of misdirection comes from the fact that we forget the question of why Navorski has come to America. This is just as well because you never would have guessed the reason and where "The Terminal" is different from other Spielberg movies is that the big moment really is a small moment, which is why it is the better of these two collaborations.
summary: Steven Spielberg and Tom Hanks pair up for light comedy

reviewText: As with all over-hyped movies, I had difficulty forcing myself into watching this one.  However, once I did I was glad I took the time to watch it.  Not that it is a great movie; it is not.  But this movie is a modern fable that generally works and has a few good laughs along the way.Viktor Navorski is traveling to the United States and has just arrived in New York City.  Unfortunately, there was a war in his home country of Krakozhia and now Viktor can not enter New York and he can not return to his home country.  The friendly Department of Homeland Security person, Frank Dixon (Stanley Tucci), advises Viktor to stay in the airport because if he leaves Dixon will have him arrested.What follows is a humorous character study.  While some may fault the movie for the lack of depth, viewers need to consider that Viktor was seeing life from a viewpoint that provided no depth, and director Stephen Spielberg exploited that lack of depth.  We slowly learn a lot about the various denizens of the airport, which includes Enrique Cruz (Diego Luna), Gupta Rajan (Kumar Pallana), Officer Torres (Zoe Saldana) and Catherine Zeta-Jones as stewardess and love-interest Amelia Warren.We soon learn that each of these people, who we see but briefly as we rush to our plane or zoom by on the way to a taxi, are three dimensional people with extraordinary backgrounds.  Even Frank Dixon has his own foibles and petty habits that are used to humorous effect.  Amelia and Viktor begin a relationship that eventually becomes the focus of the movie.  However, Viktor has a mystery that is revealed only when the time is right.There are parts of this movie that I did not enjoy.  I thought Amelia was shallow and ditzy, though her character was purposefully this way to help Viktor realize why he was in the United States.  I thought Frank Dixon was stereotypical and far too callous and vindictive.  I was particularly puzzled by his actions at the end of the movie, which seemed uncharacteristic given all that came before.  I think Spielberg was trying to show that anyone can become a better person given the right circumstances, but I was not convinced.On the other hand, there was a lot about this movie that I enjoyed.  It was funny in a lot of places.  It was also heart-warming in places.  Once Viktor's secret was revealed (which you will have to discover for yourself), Amelia's purpose in the movie became clear to me.  Indeed, a viewer should recognize that Viktor was tempted to stray from his mission, and he nearly did, but in the end the resolution that kept him going through the months in the airport was what allowed him to keep his focus.  The end of the movie is somewhat like a Frank Capra movie, but we need more movies like that as an alternative to the mind-numbing violence, sex and special effects that accompany so many movies in place of a plot.I am a little surprised by the PG-13 rating, because the movie was relatively tame and I think I would allow most children to ages 7 or 8 watch it, though there are a lot of things they would not understand.  I would hesitate to call this movie a family movie, unless your children are teenagers.If you are looking for a diversion, and a few laughs, and you can tolerate a slightly less than happy ending, then give this movie a shot.

reviewText: Steven Spielberg has made a career of allowing grownups to act like children. In THE TERMINAL, he presents an initially believable premise that soon morphs into a touchy feely ending that allows all wrongs to be set right.  Spielberg takes the true story of an Iranian immigrant who, through no fault of his own, was stranded in Kennedy Airport, and adds to it a series of supporting characters who, by the film's end, march in solidarity to rout the forces of an intrusive government bureaucracy.  Tom Hanks is Viktor Navorsky, who is headed from a fictional eastern European nation to Kennedy Airport.  On route, he discovers that his government has been overthrown, his passport rendered invalid, and he himself is now stateless.  So far so good, but Spielberg felt the need to balance Navorsky's essential goodness against the uncompromising lack of compassion evinced by the airport's chief of security (Stanley Tucci). It is a big pill to swallow to accept that everyone else in the film, including Tucci's own security people, are really rooting for Navorsky to be granted permission to exit the airport legally.  Hanks, speaking both a fractured English and a Russian dialect that is reasonably Slavic to the trained Russian ear, is convincing as the Man With No Country.  Catherine Zeta-Jones, as Amelia the flight attendant who takes a shine to Viktor, is much less convincing as the "other woman" in a relation with a married man.  The Zeta-Jones character is your stereotypical "stay away from me because I am all messed up" female, who in one scene wants to grow close to Viktor, then in the next backs away, and then still in the next, changes her mind once again.The major problem I had with THE TERMINAL has nothing to do with Hanks.  Rather, Spielberg goes for the cheap feel good connection of audience sympathy for Viktor. How can anyone possibly root against a guy who not only manages to survive on his own in a foreign airport, but also manages to speak quite adequate colloquial English half way through?  This is on top of making more money as a union carpenter than does the Tucci character as head of airport security.  Further, Spielberg peppers the supporting cast with the requisite and proportional ethnic mix of Hispanic, Afro-American, and Indian, all of whom are prepared to risk their personal freedom to support Viktor in his pursuit of a visa.  I do not believe THE TERMINAL is meant as an allegory of heavy handed bureaucracy.  It seems more likely that Spielberg wanted to place Hanks in a reverse of his earlier CAST AWAY role as a fish out of water who needs to adapt to survive.  In both roles Hanks suggests that survival can be seen as darkly serious or lightly humorous.  How one interprets it is more a function of the audience than the director.

reviewText: Tom Hanks plays a visitor from a small European country who is trapped in New York's JFK airport indefinitely when a revolution in his homeland invalidates his paperwork. He can't go forward, and he can't go back, so he ekes out a life for himself in the airport, with an airport bureaucrat becoming increasingly obsessed with the idea of getting rid of him. In the end, he is able to return to his homeland in triumph, having completed a lifelong quest to get an autograph to complete the collection of his dead father. The first third of the movie was terrific; seeing Hanks learning how to cope with his airport life, and the early annoyances of Stanley Tucci, was a lot of fun. In the second third of the movie, the plot starts to come apart a little bit. A romance between a baggage handler and a customer service representative becomes the focus for a while, and Hanks pursues a relationship with stewardess Zeta-Jones. Some of the scenes begin to ring a little false, and the dialogue begins to feel a little strained. Zeta-Jones starts to seem annoying rather than charming. In the final act, a huge tidal wave of schmaltz rolls in, obliterating everything in its path. The baggage handler gets married in an amazingly unbelievable sequence. Tucci comes unhinged, and gets obsessed with Hanks, although he inexplicably refuses to do anything to make Hanks less comfortable (such as disrupting his sleeping, blowing the whistle on an off-the-books job he lands). Hanks reveals the secret of his visit to America, an unlikely mission to procure an autograph from a Jazz musician. Hanks sacrifices his dream for his airport friends, and they in turn sacrifice themselves for his dream. Hanks gathers a cult following from all the airport employees, who begin posting Xeroxes of his hand all over in a show of support and admiration. Zeta-Jones makes a deal to help Hanks, but somehow agreed to get back together with an abusive married man to seal the deal. And a cadre of airport security guards, poised to arrest Hanks as he leaves the airport, steps aside in a display of human compassion. In the entire list of actions I just ticked off, not a single one seemed remotely believable, and their combined weight dragged down any of the enjoyable aspects of the film.

He's come to America and has landed in the JFK airport. While he was in the air his country was overtaken by local rebels. His passport is no longer legal and he can't get a visa. He can't enter the U.S. without a visa, and he can't go home because his passport is no longer recognized by the United States since his goverment isn't functional. He's a small crack in a huge system and all of this is explained to him from Security Director Frank Dixon(Tucci). He can do one thing and that is stay in the airport. He can't leave the terminal until peace is established and the U.S. will recognize his leaders.Viktor doesn't understand it at first but quickly catches on. He has no money, because his countries money is no good. He's given a few provisions by the airport, but he quickly loses them. So he does what Dixon says, and he stays in the terminal.He quickly starts to learn in the terminal. He eats crackers with ketchup and mustard for a while until he finds an easy way to get money. He lives in gate 67 which is closed for repairs. He fins an alternative source for food when he meets Enrique(Diego) a gourmet food supplier who quickly gives him food for information about one of the woman in the airport that he loves. They become friends along with Enriques other comrades Ray and Gupta(Henley & Pallana).While in the Terminal Viktor gets a job with the construction crew. He starts earning good money and he meets a woman that he quickly is enchanted by. Amelia(Jones) is a flight attendant at the airport. She is in there every couple of weeks and is dating a married man. She isn't happy with her life and Viktor tries to change that. There friendship develops and we find out the reason that Viktor came to America. I won't reveal anymore of the story because I don't want to spoil anymore.Tom Hanks is the man in this movie. He delivers the best performance of 2004 to this date with the character Viktor Navorski. His accent is fantastic and he even changes the normal way that he walks to play him. Like he did in Philadelphia, he becomes the character and you no longer see Tom Hanks. That's he's one of the best in the business, because of the so many memorable characters he's been. This is one of the best he's done and he has to be the early Oscar favorite.This is a limited role for Catherine Zeta Jones. She doesn't get a lot of screen time, but when she's on it she's memroable. It's a totally different look for one of the worlds most beautiful woman and she pulls it off. Some say this role is a waste of the Oscar winners talents, but they are so wrong. There isn't a trace of her heavy Welsh accent at all in the movie. She plays Amelia to perfection. She is easily one of the most talented actresses in the world and she doesn't disappoint.Only Spielberg could have made this movie. Everything is perfectly done in it. You feel like you are in an actual airport. Everything is authentic. This is one of the best sets ever done in a movie. The shots are great and this movie is so well made. Spielberg is a perfectionist and you can tell that by how well made this is.The story in this moive is awesome. It's a great tale of love and frienship. The theater I was in had people cheering and some were crying. It does drag at times, but it's not that bad. There are a lot of characters and all are developed well. We see a complete change in a man, and it couldn't have been done well in a 90 minute movie.I love this moive. In my opinion it's the best movie of the year to this date. I've seen it twice and the left the theater smiling and happy each time. It's another classic from two of the best in the business with Hanks and Spielberg. Go see The Terminal and prepare yourself for a great time.

reviewText: A noted critic is famous for saying that the worst movie the Marx brothers could ever make would still be better than most films out there. That's how director Steven Spielberg is these days - though not at the top of his critical or popular peak, he continues to make movies that - though not shoo-ins for a Top 100 list - are 'good.' Case in point: The Terminal is the worst movie he's made in a decade, and I still had a pretty good time.If anything, The Terminal (like Young Adam with Ewan McGregor) proves that an immensely talented star and American Everyman like Tom Hanks can rise above just about anything and make it worthwhile. His plight as the immigrant stuck in the airport terminal is alternately hilarious, touching, and so incredibly nuanced that you do - believe me on this - forget it's a megastar playing the role. Hanks plays the role with a Chaplinesque grace that compliments everyone around him, especially airport workers Diego Luna, Kumar Pallana, and Zoe Saldana. And the movie works...to a point. What I found most shocking about Terminal is that it really comes apart with the introduction of the plot strand involing Catherine Zeta-Jones' flight attendant. Her Amelia is a schlocky, As the World Turns-inspired piece of character writing that is too often contrived and sappy. And unconvincing at that - quite a feat considering Zeta-Jones is the most beautiful woman on the planet.I don't really know what was going through the minds of writers Sacha Gervasi and Jeff Nathanson when they decided to throw this movie away in its final act. This movie has so much wistful charm it's easy to throw off the 'Amelia situation' and succeed, but the plot spotlight hits her too much near the end; and it gets so sappy. Ebert hails Spielberg as an American director who can make audiences cry without manipulation, but The Terminal becomes too noodging as one act of kindness after another guides the movie to its close. And I admired the film's aim for simplicity in its final tie of the plot strands (yes, this movie turns on a peanut canister), but as the credits rolled, I felt a vague feeling of dissatisfaction (a la A.I.).It's difficult to really judge a movie like this. The charm, heart, and wit displayed in most of it is enough to keep it afloat despite some serious missteps, but let me take a minute and be unfair. This is a director who has helmed some of the most enduring works of American film...so why didn't he notice some the soap opera-ish writing and cheesiness that pops up too often in this film? I look toward the movie's faults more because I know they could have been fixed: Amelia could have been more believable, the movie could have left out some "awww" moments at the end, and it could have trimmed off about 10 minutes. Had The Terminal taken the time to match the perfection of the film's first half, it would have been one of the best movies of the year. I had such a great time for a while, and wanted to follow it to even greater things. Even now, though, it's a warm, engaging little comedy stuck in an overlong melodrama's body. GRADE: B
summary: Has its issues, but is irresistably charming and sweet...

reviewText: Why did this movie get such crappy reviews when it was released?! I'll tell you why: because movie critics SUCK! "The Terminal" is an endearing little movie. Yes, the plot is pretty unrealistic, but who cares? Tom Hanks plays Victor Navorski, an Eastern European who arrives at JFK International Airport in New York City just as a military coup has overtaken the government in his homeland. As a result, Navorski has no valid citizenship, and airport officials inform him that he is not allowed to enter the United States and cannot return back to his own country: he is literally banished to the airport. Victor manages to make the most of his situation, finding gainful employment and even wooing a [slightly unstable] flight attendant (Catherine Zeta Jones).Hanks is the best part of this movie, by far. I'm not sure if this film would have worked with any other actor in the leading role, but watching Hanks saw apart airport seats to furnish a comfortable bed and race around the airport returning baggage carts in order to earn a few quarters really warms your heart. Zeta Jones delivers a solid performance in her supporting role, and Stanley Tucci is great as the uptight terminal director. Kumar Pallana also has a great supporting role as a janitor. (People who saw him in "The Royal Tenenbaums" will delight in the fact that he performs all the juggling/plate-spinning tricks that he did in the bonus features of the "Tenenbaums" DVD!) "The Terminal" is a sweet movie that is definitely worth watching..I highly recommend it!(An interesting production note: I watched a little behind the scenes special on "The Terminal" when it first opened in theatres, and I was surprised to learn that the entire airport in the film was a movie set...none of it was filmed on location. The set was HUGE, and it consisted of all the offices, airport lobbies, terminals, and the large shopping center. Very impressive!)
summary: A bit unrealistic, but a charming little movie nonetheless!

reviewText: The movie world of Steven Spielberg is one of good and evil and the struggle between the two. Think "AI" and "The Minority Report" and as far back as "Jaws" for that matter.Spielberg is America's foremost humanist filmmaker; his films are similar in subject matter to Tim Burton, for example but far, far away from Burton in style and execution.In "The Terminal" you have the good guy, Viktor Navorski (the ultimate Uber good guy, Tom Hanks) and his nemesis: primarily the US government and it's attendant red tape but represented in the person of Frank Dixon (Stanley Tucci).Stuck in the International terminal of Kennedy airport, unable to actually step onto USA territory...NYC to be exact through a series of circumstances, not of his own making, Viktor, instead of moping about, makes the best of the situation and lives day-to-day as best he can. Can you imagine a New Yorker of a Los Angeleno sleeping on a hard airline bench without needing psychiatric help within 24 hours?In what is basically a cameo, Catherine Zeta-Jones plays a wounded, always hopeful soul who has a brief encounter with Viktor and is better but not wiser for it. She is very beautiful and very sad."The Terminal" is Spielberg at his most touching and emotional and even though he veers towards the maudlin on a couple of occasions, he narrowly misses actually going there: he is an artist who understands that you must risk the ridiculous in order to achieve the sublime.

reviewText: There are certain films you want to go see, and then there are films you decide to go see. Spiderman 2, The Bourne Supremacy, Collateral, Anchorman, Aliens vs. Predator, all films I am dying to see, no doubt. But, those are granted films I'm going to walk out of happy and fulfilled. Now with certain films, the ones you decide to go see, that's where enjoyment is really, something extraordinary. Take for tonight, 'The Terminal', starring Tom Hanks and Catherine Zeta Jones, was one of those rarities. I walked out of this film satisfied and I would like to explain why.'The Terminal' is by far one of Spielberg's most indirect projects I have ever seen. It was never hyped, it was never planned for the longest time, it just was. But, for some reason, it has this look that shines above many of Spielberg's works. From the certain lighting to the timid, noble acting of Tom Hanks, there is a difference mixture here and I think anyone who has seen a Spielberg movie should see this.The film is simple, but it's different, that alone makes it intriguing. But, the trailers to me weren't, they made me actually NOT want to see the film, something rare when the name Spielberg was attached. What the trailer didn't show is what couldn't be shown. This film is a walking painting, there is so much to see and so much to love that no three minutes will pull you in.You're taken into this world, a new world, a new country...Terminal 67. Hanks plays a Russian-esque civilian coming to NY and is stuck in this new area. Much like a pseudo-Dawn of the Dead, he makes this his living area, and that's when things become interesting. From the uncanny, mall like lounge that featurs a Borders, Hugo Boss, Brookstone, etc to the dilapidated past that is being redone, everything shines here and we are enveloped into this world that someone adapts into.Spielberg's work is amazing. Atleast in this film. I kept finding myself saying, 'Nice shot', 'Beautiful', or 'Wow.' The colors he has are so, clear, so high definition, and in a way, they paralell with the late Stanley Kubrick. You just really should see it to see what and where I am coming from.The subplots and everything really pull you in. You want to know what is going to happen next, it's like what Pigvomit said in Private Parts, the people watch Howard to see what happens. This is entirely the case here. The different things Hanks does for people and the extraordinary characteristics of different people are really intriguing. Contrary to what most reviewers said, CNN being one them, many of the interactions are not inplausible, and even so, this is like reading a book, almost imagination, but really, it is rather realistic.To me, this is a surprise. I know many here won't like this picture, many will consider it boring, but I don't see how. It's not a campy love story, it's a story of just how far one will go and how can they. It's decent. That could be my review there, it's decent. It didn't pop out and make me go insane like Catch Me If You Can or Saving Private Ryan, but it made me think and say, 'interesting.' I say that's much more rewarding than a few cheap laughs and thrills at say, Riddick or the bland, Dodgeball.It's a really different kind of film and for a summer with so many holes in hit films, this really shines, at least for, at least until June 30th when the ride begins.Spielberg, I applaud, not a standing ovation, but a pat on the back. Same goes to Hanks, who I found pivotal.

reviewText: "The Terminal" was apparently inspired by several cases of travelers without acceptable documentation who have spent inordinate periods of time -sometimes years- waiting in limbo in airport transit lounges. This take on the tale is a romantic dramedy set in New York's JFK Airport. Viktor Navorski (Tom Hanks) is a traveler visiting the United States from the fictional Eastern European Republic of Krakozhia, which has suffered a military coup while Victor was in flight. Without a recognized government, all passports issued by Krakozhia are suspended and all visas revoked. Victor is stranded. The airport's chief of security, Frank Dixon (Stanley Tucci) confines him to the International Transit Lounge at JFK until things are sorted out in his homeland. While he waits, Victor develops friendships with airport staff, gets mixed up in customs issues, and romances a flight attendant, Amelia (Catherine Zeta-Jones). All the while, a vindictive Dixon tries every method he can devise to get Victor to leave the airport so that he will be some other law enforcement agency's problem.Tom Hanks is affable and charming in his usual way. Catherine Zeta-Jones is given little to do except look pretty. Stanley Tucci makes Dixon appropriately unlikable, but Dixon's behavior is rarely clearly motivated. He seems to be there only because the film needs a conflict. Most of "The Terminal" is spent watching Victor bungle his way around the Transit Lounge trying to find ways to make money or win the lady. I suppose this is supposed to be funny or sympathetic. It is for a while, but it's endless. There just isn't much story. "The Terminal" is a Tom Hanks vehicle with almost nothing hitched to it. Hanks' performance is the story, but this is not "Cast Away". A sweet funny guy living in an airport does not possess 2 hours of entertainment value. The DVD (Universal/Dreamworks 2004) has no bonus features. Dubbing is available in French. Subtitles are available in English, Spanish, and French.
summary: Long and Sweet. Unfortunately, Nothing More.

reviewText: I finally managed to check out "The Terminal" a couple of weeks ago at the theater, and I must say that I, for one, was really impressed with the way Academy Award-winning director Steven Spielberg ("Saving Private Ryan", "Schindler's List") had outdone himself with this wonderfully lighthearted comedy-drama which is sure to be the best Spielberg film since his recent hit comedy-adventure, "Catch Me If You Can"! Spielberg's direction of "The Terminal" could not be better! The performance of two-time Academy Award winner Tom Hanks (Best Actor, 1993 and 1994: "Philadelphia" and "Forrest Gump") was brilliant, funny, and top-notch! This is possibly Hanks' best performance since "Sleepless in Seattle"! The performance of fellow Academy Award winner Catherine Zeta-Jones (Best Supporting Actress, 2002: "Chicago") was charming, sweet, and unforgettable! Rounding out the cast are Stanley Tucci ("Road to Perdition"), Chi McBride (TV's "Boston Public"), Diego Luna ("Open Range", "Dirty Dancing: Havana Nights"), Kumar Pallana ("The Royal Tenenbaums"), and Zoe Saldana ("Crossroads", "Pirates of the Caribbean: The Curse of the Black Pearl"), in which they, too, gave excellent performances alongside the two leads."The Terminal" focuses on Viktor Navorski (Hanks), an eager, disheveled traveler from Eastern Europe. After arriving at his gate at New York's JFK International Airport, Viktor is getting ready to pass through customs when he learns that he can't go anywhere. The reason is that there has been a military coup in his native (and fictional) country of Krakozhia, and his passport is rendered invalid. Officially, he's a "citizen of nowhere", ordered to stay within the confines of the International Transit Lounge. Viktor, who speaks fragments of English, carries an old Planters peanuts tin around with him, and its mystery contents, we gather, are connected to the reason for his journey. Will he ever make it to Manhattan--or, more precisely, to the Ramada Inn on Lexington Avenue? Oh the sadness, the irony of it! He has arrived to fulfill his dream in America, and they won't even let him in!You'd think it would be a temporary problem. The snarly, rulebound security officer, Frank Dixon (Tucci), would like to be rid of Viktor, he even tries to goad him into escaping. But Viktor is a dutiful and passive soul, and he won't even venture out. Viktor remains at the airport in limbo, and the hours stretch into days, weeks, months. Viktor is given food vouchers, which he promptly loses, and he gets shunted around without any thought to his physical comfort. But luckily for Viktor, he takes all of it in stride. He returns stray baggage carts for the reward of a quarter apiece to obtain food, and he appears to hone his English by reading the ticker on TV news channels, mostly to check on Krakozhia's situation. But Spielberg, working from a script by Sachi Gervasi and Jeff Nathanson (the story is by Gervasi and Andrew Niccol of "The Truman Show"), turns Viktor's stay at JFK mostly into a fish-out-of-water lark. During his stay in the airport, Viktor makes the most of his time by befriending many of the airport employees, including a baggage handler (McBride), a coyle hostile Indian santitation worker (Pallana), who enjoys watching people slip on freshly cleaned floors even after the "Wet Floor" signs have been placed on the surface, and Viktor agrees to play Cupid for Enrique (Luna), who's secretly in love with a sexy customs officer named Torres (Saldana). Viktor also develops a chaste flirtation of his own: He keeps running into Amelia Warren (Zeta-Jones), a breathless flight attendant whose romantic life is a case study in doormat cluelessness. She falls in love with Viktor while also being drawn to his deep-down nobility.In conclusion, the team of Tom Hanks and Steven Spielberg is going strong and could not be better, especially because "The Terminal", by far, could be their best work together since "Saving Private Ryan" and "Catch Me If You Can"! "The Terminal" has everything that a comedy-drama should have: a splendid all-star cast and the great characters that they portray, laugh-out-loud humor, remarkable storytelling, heartfelt emotion, and a great soundtrack that Academy Award-winning composer John Williams ("Minority Report", The "Indiana Jones" and "Star Wars" films) can provide us with! "The Terminal" is, without a doubt, when released, a worthy DVD must have to my Tom Hanks/Steven Spielberg collection!
summary: Hanks' and Spielberg's best since "Catch Me If You Can"!!

reviewText: The Terminal, starring Tom Hanks, Stanley Tucci, and Catherine Zeta-Jones, revolves around an Eastern European man who is stranded in JFK international airport. (While in flight, a military coup occurs in his country, which renders his passport invalid. He becomes a man without a country.) He stays in the airport for several months, waiting for conditions in his country to change.Some of the scenes in the movie were the saddest, sweetest scenes that I've seen on screen in quite a while. When Victor (Hanks) is briefed by airport officials about what has happened in his country, his limited English prevents him from understanding. It is only later, when he sees images of his country on an airport television, that he begins to comprehend what has occurred. He becomes almost hysterical. Again, his limited English prevents him from fully understanding the news reports, and no one will help him use a phone card to call home and learn news of his loved ones. He is basically left to fend for himself in the airport terminal.In scenes like these, it seemed to me that Spielberg was really trying to emphasize the isolation of American culture, especially that of big cities. (Very Hopper-esque.) Everyone is too busy to help. No one takes pity on Victor. And the fact that almost the entire movie takes place in an airport terminal - a transitional space, not a destination, people are neither here nor there, they are only almost somewhere - seemed to illustrate the transience of life.Slowly, Victor acclimates to life in the terminal (!), and our faith in humanity is restored. Even in a bustling airport, Victor begins to make friends, people begin to help him. (As Victor is befriended by the airport staff members, I started to feel much better about the movie. Coming from a small city, the story of the good samaritan is something that I'm much more familiar with. I can't imagine someone being abandoned at the Jackson International Airport, for goodness sakes! I know that someone would take pity on him!)Victor is always waiting, and we learn throughout the movie that other characters are waiting, too - for love, for the other shoe to drop, for their dreams to be fulfilled. Victor learns, as do some of the other characters, that life is what is happening while we are waiting for life to happen. It was a very enjoyable, very interesting movie.

reviewText: Ok, I just watched this DVD and I thought I would boot up the ol' computer to get online and review it while it is still hot on my mind.  In some ways this movie made me angry.  Why? Gee wiz someone's country gets into a war that makes it so he cannot go back and he is also prevented from entering into the USA.  Surely computers run on a rigid to the letter protocol but they cannot think and reason.  They do not know how to, they just do what they are told, nothing more...nothing less.  Humans, on the other hand are not computers and can think and reason but yet it appears we choose not to and therefore, we have so much become like them.  It is all about protocol, it is all about policy, it is all about rules.  There is no room for thinking, there is not room for reason.  This movie hits it on the head and boy does it hit a nerve. Ouch!As other reviewers have said, this movie does have charm and warmth.  While the "powers that be" are stuck in their protocol, the workers at the airport begin to help out the man without a country.  Then there is the dippy stewardess who is too busy hating men to see her own problems that cause here to hate men.  Hello! Mrs Dippy is 'farin' with a married man who is down-lowin'. First he tries to get him to break the law and leave the airport by unsecuring the front doors.  Then trying to convince the man he is afraid to return to his home country.  These ploys don't work. I really would have loved to see this character get his just deserts but then he was the one we all loved to hate.  As to this villianous character, there did not really seem to be a reason to have so much malice toward the man without a country.  It was not like he was going to get fired over it - least that was not what the storyline was depicting. We live in a country where every one is an island, where it's all about "my space", "what I want", "me first and to heck with everyone else".  In all of our freedom, we enslave ourselves to selfishness, ego, and pride, in our freedom, we are not happy unless we hold others down.In the end things work out, but at what cost?And, ok so the trapped traveler finally gets to achieve his objective and now he wants to "go home".  So how is he going to get by at the airport?

In the beginning adjusting to life in the terminal is harrowing what with the whole place being designed for people on the move. With no place to sleep he improvises by detaching the seats in the lounge and arranging them in line using them as a makeshift couch. He shaves and bathes in the toilet and eats the free crackers and mustard left behind by customers at various fast food outlets. We also discover how Mr. Viktor Naworski touches people's lives by random and sometimes unintentional acts and words of kindness. Based loosely on a true story about an out-of-country traveler stuck at an airport because of a revolution back in his home country - this rendering the traveler "countryless". The real story took place in France (with an Iranian immigrant), but Spielberg brought this version to the USA, namely New York's "JFK" Airport (with Hanks' character from the fictional country of Krakozhia). Hanks, as Viktor Navorski, total transforms himself into the homeless man now living at Terminal 67. The set design is wonderful - and not once did I believe that I was not at JFK Airport. Yes, JFK Airport is used in the movie in the wide shots, but the up close material is not the airport. I read the set design was extensive - built in an old hangar with name brand restaurants and stores. Only thing missing in this movie was some outdoor scenery (you got only a glimpse of the outdoors at the very end of the movie - Viktor's exit from JFK in the snow, and then a quick cab ride down Broadway). Hanks acting (Bulgarian accent et all) was incredible - and outside of "Ladykillers" (also from 2004), he hasn't made a bad movie in decades. I truly believe he is one of Hollywood's top 2-3 male actors in the business today. Catherine Zeta-Jones (as mixed-up flight attendent Amelia) was very good as a co-star. Though I must admit, I would've been disappointed if Amelia and Viktor ended up together (Amelia didn't deserve Viktor at all). Bald man Stanley Tucci ("Imposters", "The Core", "Consiracy", "Kiss Of Death") was great as the heartless Airport commissioner, Frank Dixon. When I saw the trailer in the movie theater I was not inspired to see "The Terminal" at all. Even though it was Tom Hanks, it just didn't strike me as a good subject for a movie. I went into this movie expecting nothing and I was totally amazed by the story and the acting. Only bad thing I can mention about "The Terminal" DVD is that there are absolutely NO extras. reviewText: **1/2Viktor Navorski is a man without a country - literally.  On the very day his plane touches down at JFK, Viktor learns that a coup has occurred back in his fictional home country of Krakozha.  Among other inconveniences, this international crisis renders his passport invalid until the United States government agrees to recognize and establish diplomatic relations with the destabilized country's new leadership.  Until then, Viktor remains a virtual prisoner in the terminal, unable to leave the premises and forced to live under the watchful eye of airport security.  There's a certain irony in the fact that Viktor, who was presumably raised in a draconian communist country, becomes the ultimate victim of a de-humanized bureaucracy and a mountain of red tape the minute he sets foot on American soil.  From that moment on, he has to find a way to survive in this strange new environment, but eventually he learns to make the airport his home, winning friends and wooing a love interest (played by Catherine Zeta-Jones) into the bargain.Certainly, there are those who will find this fable about a simple man, trapped somewhere between the worlds of Capra and Kafka, heartwarming and charming.  All I can say is that I found it, for the most part, aggravatingly contrived and cutesy, too infatuated with its own premise to develop a sustainable storyline.  The problem begins with Tom Hanks who has milked the Average Joe/ Mr. Nice Guy shtick so much throughout his long career that it has long since lost any impact it once might have had.  Adding a cutesy Eastern European accent to the brew just makes the performance all that more insufferable.  In essence, Victor is reduced to little more than a "man/child," hardly a character worth developing a full length, tour de force feature film around.Steven Spielberg, who normally can do no wrong as a director, for some reason is unable to make an effective go of things here.  Could it be because Spielberg handles sentiment well when he's working in a generally unsentimental genre like science fiction where he has some built-in tension to work off of, but that when he's dabbling in a highly sentimental genre like romantic comedy, he runs out of energy and vision?  He's done a terrific job recreating an entire functioning airport terminal on a soundstage, but none of that really matters very much when we begin feeling as trapped inside the setting as Viktor himself does.  Throughout the whole movie, I just kept wishing Viktor would bust his way through the terminal doors and find his way into a more interesting story.  Almost all the secondary characters are shallow, stereotypical and uninteresting, while Stanley Tucci's nasty little airport manager is not only annoying and repulsive but completely incomprehensible from a psychological point of view."The Terminal" is one of those movies that is so impressed with its own sweetness and goodness that it winds up patronizing all the "little people" it thinks it's celebrating.  This is a film strictly for those who actually enjoy being stuck at the airport.

reviewText: Unil I saw The Terminal, I was not a fan of Tom Hanks.  I thought of him as a McActor, the Jimmy Stewart or Gary Cooper of his generation.  A competent but not compelling actor. He doesn't speak English.  A quirk in customs regulations causes Viktor to be confined overnight at the airport.  Bureaucratic bungling turns Viktor's confinement into an extended stay.  Viktor's bureaucratic tormenter is the heartless and mean-spirited Frank Dixon, Director of Customs and Border Protection, played to snarling perfection by Stanley Tucci.A memorable scene is when Viktor presents Dixon with a taxidermed Virgin Isle swordfish to add to the collection of fishing trophies proudly displayed on the walls of his office.  The fish is almost as big as Viktor.  Not only does the peevish official viciously reject the gift, he promises Viktor "You will not set one foot in New York City.  Not a single toe in the United States of America.  Do you understand what I am saying to you?"You see the anger welling up in Viktor.  He is about to explode with rage, about to flatten the bully with a well-deserved roundhouse right, or at least curse him out.  Then he summons his better instincts.  "Yes.  You don't like fish," he says and walks out.  Viktor is too decent a man to stoop to Dixon's level. The scene finishes with a light dollop of comedy as Viktor clumsily drags the outsized fish out the door.Of course people like Viktor don't really exist.  The movie is pure fantasy about a world as we wish it could be.  It is full of brotherhood and camaraderie among airport employees.  We all know that in the real world, the workplace is full of backstabbing, one-upmanship, and cutthroat competition.This airport is a joyous place to work whereas a real one is peopled with workers struggling to cope with crushing drudgery.  The workers at this airport are good-hearted, loveable characters and pretty women like Zoe Saldana, who plays Torres, the comely bureaucrat who dutifully stamps "DENIED" on Viktor's daily application to be released from his terminal purgatory.So what's wrong with a little fantasy?  If you can buy into it, The Terminal is rewarding movie.  You would have to watch at least three other movies to experience all the heartwarming, romantic, and funny touches in The Terminal.The Hollywood blockbuster playbook dictates a bittersweet romance. reviewText: For all Steven Spielberg's directorial gifts, brevity is not one of them. The worst film he has made since "1941" 25 years ago, "The Terminal" is aptly named - a 90-minute concept stretched a full hour beyond its expiration date, with only a accent-bearing, shambling Tom Hanks to accompany us.Spielberg's film fails on more than one level, but mostly because he saddles the central plot - a man forced to live in the international terminal of New York's JFK Airport - with a collection of either forgotten or underdeveloped side stories that pay lip service to diversity - a Latino, a black guy, a black girl, an Indian janior, a beautiful stewardess - without making much of use of them until the last half-hour, when these cardboard cutouts suddenly claim a stake in the game.You think "Return of the King" had too many endings? Just wait. And wait.Hanks is Viktor Navorski, a native of the fictional Krakovia, where rebels have overthrown the government. Viktor is in New York on a trip whose motiviation remains unspecified until very late in the film. With his country in the throes of a coup, his passport and visa are no longer valid. Homeland Security agent Frank Dixon (Stanley Tucci) tells Viktor bluntly with a bag of chips smashed by an apple: Viktor can't go home, and he can't go to New York. He's shown the terminal, and the doors to New York through which he cannot pass.What follows is a mix of Frank Capra fable and a human jungle version of Hanks' "Cast Away." Viktor builds a makeshift bed out of torn seats at an abandoned gate; he finds quarters to buy Burger King cheeseburgers (at a cheaper cost than you'd ever find in an airport); he makes friends with a baggage handler (Chi McBride), the janitor (Kumar Pallanatucci) and a food service worker (Diego Luna) smitten with an INS agent (Zoe Saldana); and he flirts with the Midwestern stewardness (a perky Catherine Zeta-Jones), a psuedo-intellectual who is the mistress of a wealthy, married man.Viktor also turns down Dixon's offers to help him into New York, where he can become, Dixon thinks, "someone else's problem." Viktor won't leave on his own. He refuses asylum. Dixon won't detain Viktor until he's broken some law, although, I would think, taking payments under the table to do construction work in the airport is reasonably illegal.The movie's turning point occurs when a Russian man threatens to kill himself unless he's allowed to deliver Canadian medicine to his dying father; Dixon calls in Viktor to translate, and Viktor's solution, clever as it may be, is so prepostorous that it  takes "The Terminal" off whatever rail its was still hugging and straight into foolishness: A marriage proposal, an elaborate, mosaic fountain built out of ceramic scraps, a cruel blackmail by Dixon and, yes, a jumbo jet brought to a halt by a wet mop.Despite his two Oscars, Hanks is more gifted than critics give him credit for, and his subtle comic work as Viktor works much better than his recent turn in "The Ladykillers." Tucci, until his character is forced to become vengeful, embodies a decent-yet-prideful Dixon. If there is a couple in this film, it's these two. Hanks and Zeta-Jones have zero chemistry - their kiss is in long shot, with the camera pulling away - and the downbeat end note on their relationship provides the lone beacon of reality in "The Terminal." The set design by Alex McDowell is quite flawless - this might as well be a working airport - and yet Spielberg never does much with it. He so immerses himself in these subplots that the airport becomes a stale gimmick.But, more frustrating, is a screenplay, by Jeff Nathanson and Sacha Gervasi, that actually conspires to keep Viktor - and us - waiting longer than he needs to be. "Everybody has a story," Dixon says at one point, and if Viktor were allowed to explain his reason for being in New York to anyone but a stewardess who doesn't even know Viktor lives in the airport, it's quite likely that something could have been "arranged."Would "The Terminal" have the been the same movie? No. It would have been a better one.

reviewText: In Steven Spielberg's "The Terminal", Tom Hanks stars as Viktor Navorski, who comes to New York City from his home country of Krakohzia, unfortunately, just as the government is overthrown in a military coup. Now, as his country is now "no longer recognized" by the United Nations, his tickets and passport are invalid, and he is stranded between America and Krakohzia; within the terminal at JFK airport. Speaking little English and without American money, Viktor's temporary stay turns into 9 months where he creates a home for himself, befriending airport employees (Chi McBride, Diego Luna, Kumar Pullana) and annoying Frank Dixon (Stanley Tucci), a security executive who feels Viktor is a threat to his strive for a promotion. Viktor also falls in love with flight attendant Amelia Warren (Catherine Zeta-Jones), who always seems to be with the wrong man.Lately, after creating films to challenge our perception of reality and of the future, "The Terminal" is a nice change for Spielberg, who seems to return to the similar genre every so often. It's not exactly hard-hitting, but it's entertaining, and a whimsical idea for a film that is executed well, even more so with a brilliant Hanks attached to the role of Viktor Navorksi. In a difficult to understand accent, and a sort of confused yet resourceful and humorous manner, the audience is immediately taken up with him. He plays to the compassionate side of the audience, and we can't help but to ooze sympathy and root for him throughout the film. He is, in a sense, the perfect leading man. As a supporting cast, Tucci is fantastic as Frank Dixon, and Diego Luna is perfect as a lovesick airline worker. However, the real nod goes to Kumar Pallana, whose oddball and paranoid Indian janitor of a character supplies a large portion of humor in the film.Aside from the performances, the set of the terminal itself is nothing short of brillance, although it's certainly not like any airport I've ever been to. With an electrical ticket board, level upon level, and throngs of product placements, it is a massive, yet extremely realistic visual setting, that personifies the chaos of airports and traveling, and also provides a splendid backdrop for the film.While it is a good film with some solid performances and big laughs, there are many things in "The Terminal" that don't exactly work. Thanks to holes in the script, and plotlines that end up falling apart (for example, the romance between Catherine Zeta-Jones and Tom Hanks) the problems with the movie are hard to miss. While attention to detail in other areas is immaculate, the script has obvious flaws that no one seemed to catch, and some plot choices stretch our concept of what could actually happen. However, the film is funny, clever, and certainly original, and for that, it makes for an enjoyable day at the movies, despite its flaws.

reviewText: Steven Spielberg may have been tired.  Tom Hanks may have been fatigued.  Catherine Zeta-Jones was available.  What else can explain the choices that led to "The Terminal"?  Spielberg and Hanks can make feel-good movies in their sleep, and they generally hit all the right notes in this light-hearted flick."The Terminal" stars Hanks as Victor Navorsky, who arrives at JFK airport from a minor Eastern European country ("Krakozia") literally hours after Krakozia's government falls in a coup.  Victor's passport is now useless, and he is stuck in the international "lounge" (ha-ha) until the situation can be resolved.Hanks plays Victor with the earnest, lovable sincerity that only he can bring.  Victor is smart -- he teaches himself functional English by buying an English travel book and one written in his native tongue.  And he finds several different ways to earn some cash -- some believable, others not so much.  But you never really mind the bits of implausibility in Victor's tale, 'cause it's Tom Hanks.  And you can't but help love Tom Hanks.Victor has the misfortune of arriving in the airport just as Dixon (Stanley Tucci) takes over its administration.  Just as Hanks can make you fall in love with him with a glance, Tucci is one of those actors who can effortlessly evoke all the negative tones from a mid-level bureaucrat -- oily, pompous, hypocritical, and above all, just a wee bit nasty.  After about two seconds of screen time, you know that Dixon is one of those guys who enjoys telling you that the form you have waited in line all day to submit is, in fact, sorry to say, improperly filled out, and won't you please go to the back of the line after you've properly completed it?  Definitely not an evil man, but surely trumped up with his minor powers, Dixon is a perfect foil for Victor.Eventually Dixon gets tired of Victor hanging around and messing with "his airport," so he tries to get Victor to break any number of minor laws so that "he'll be someone else's problem."  But Victor, perhaps because he's familiar with this caprice from government officials back home, is too smart and refuses to break the law.  Which is impressive restraint, considering how stultifying and uncomfortable an airport environment is (a fact that the movie captures with several small, perfect scenes).As the days trundle by, Victor meets several other full-time workers at the terminal, and they all more or less fall under the spell of this charming Krakozian.  Of course, this being a Spielberg comedy, virtually all of these supporting characters are charming in their own way, and there are several genuinely heartfelt moments involving Victor's friends.There are only two low points in this movie, and I've already alluded to one.  Catherine Zeta-Jones plays a flight attendant struggling with middle age and her affair with a married man.  She meets Victor and like us can't help but falling for his adorable honesty and intelligence.  The problem isn't the character -- it's casting this actress.  Zeta-Jones is a talented actress (see "Chicago," "High Fidelity," "America's Sweethearts," and "Traffic"), but her strengths lie in playing, shall we say, less-than-admirable women.  Here, the part calls for a level of sweetness that Zeta-Jones just doesn't have, and it looks slightly ridiculous to watch her try.The other problem I have with "The Terminal" is the rampant product placement.  Tom Hanks has made some wonderful movies, but some of them start to creak under the sheer audacity of the various plugs and promos in the movie.  Anyone else recall the "Visa" and "Starbucks" scenes from "You've Got Mail"?  How about the none-too-subtle FedEx plugs in "Castaway"?  I'm not sure what Borders paid Spielberg to have its role in this movie, but I would hope that after all the billions Spielberg has made over the years, he could refrain from this kind of selling out.  I half expected to see "Borders" in the closing credits under "Bookstore In Terminal."Still, all in all, "The Terminal" is an enjoyable film appropriate for virtually all audiences.  There's an enjoyable maguffin involving Victor's can of peanuts, and several moments where you just want to reach out and hug Victor and his friends. If only an actual airport had the heart of "The Terminal" -- then traveling wouldn't be such a chore.
summary: Hanks and Spielberg Effortlessly Make Feel-Good Flick

reviewText: This comedy focuses on some of the flaws in the immigration system in the US and exposes how sometimes strict rules have to be bent for things to make sense. Everything starts when Viktor Navorski arrives to the US and is stopped at immigration on the JFK airport because his passport is invalid. That is where the nonsense begins, since even though he speaks no English, the personnel of Homeland Security talk to him really slow as if that would change his understanding of a language with which he is unfamiliar. Things just escalate from there.Viktor's country (Krakozia) has suspended his right of traveling with his passport due a political war at home that has the country in total chaos; basically there is no country. The problem is that he cannot enter the US, but he cannot return home either, so he is stranded in the airport. The solution: he has to remain in the International Transit Lounge while his situation is sorted out.Little by little we see this individual figuring out how to survive in this strange world, filling us with a sense of desperation due to his situation, but at the same time with one of hope due to his ability to cope and figure things out. Hanks is excellent in transmitting the emotions of this character, and his portrayal of a foreign citizen with an accent resembling Bulgarian is praiseworthy.The film revolves around Viktor's problem and his relationship with several people in the airport. First there is Frank (Tucci), the acting Field Commissioner of Homeland Security, who wants to get rid of Viktor in order to have less to worry about when the time comes for the inspection that will determine if he gets the position for good. Then there is Amelia Warren (Zeta-Jones), who is a stewardess that is having an affair with a married man, and who Viktor falls for at first sight. Finally, there is the relationship with other employees at the airport, which allows us to see the values of this man and how these values and convictions affect the lives of those that surround him and learn to love him.If you have ever been in the situation of having to go through security as a foreigner in a US airport (even with al the proper documentation), you will understand how the main character feels. But even if you have not experienced this before, I believe you will appreciate this film's qualities, which have to do with doing everything you can to survive and achieve your goals, using the power of friendship to surmount any obstacles and realizing that sometimes bending the rules is the right course of action.Besides the performance by Tom Hanks, this movie counts with a Stanley Tucci at the top of his game. This actor is so successful in playing annoyed guys with a miserable life that it is uncanny. Zeta-Jones provides a visual enjoyment with her beauty and an OK portrayal of Amelia, which only is sub par in the scenes that involve high emotional levels, since in my opinion she exaggerates the emotions in these cases. The final result is a nice film that will make you think and laugh, and hopefully entertain you for a little while too. - 3.5 stars.

reviewText: While the premise may at its face value be just a wee bit over-baked -- our clueless foreigner Viktor without a viable passport stranded at the JFK airport for over a year -- the reason we buy into this film's unusual mix of melodrama, comedy and romance is that it keeps our baffled immigrant grounded in very realistic interactions.Any non-American who has visited US after 2001 will readily relate to the cumbersome immigration processes, but despite that potentially boring premise for a film, Spielberg and Hanks Inc smoosh in enough bittersweet slapstick and humanity into the script.Viktor is always faced with new problems adjusting to his new life in the airport. For instance, the first problem he runs into is finding food without American money (his currency is worthless now that his country is no longer recognized) which leads him to improvise with give-away crackers, mustard, and ketchup. This meager meal seems to be a social commentary on America's wastefulness.There are various subplots with colorful characters that also keep it moving, all of which are somewhat conveniently from different backgrounds -- Spanish, Indian, Bla...oops, African American.Most notable among these is a romantic affair between Viktor and the flight stewardess Amelia (Catherine Zeta-Jones). The courting process is very cute, culminating in a date on the roof of the airport, assisted lovingly by Viktor's friends in the airport staff. That it all ends up in naught doesn't detract from the warmth of the romantic vignettes.Amidst all these peccadilloes of simple beings, the film's political messages are affecting too. Viktor's predicament is due to the newly-created and always-frantic Department of Homeland Security, which puts the airport security director in the position of wanting to wash his hands of Viktor rather than help him. In one particularly insidious moment, he encourages Viktor to leave the airport even though it is illegal, just so that he can be arrested and move to another's jurisdiction. Add to this the airport's bureaucracy, its overloaded customs traffic and a haunting scene involving a traveler desperate for Canadian prescription drugs to save his father, and The Terminal emerges as a political commentary that pulls no punches.The humour is occasionally corny, and Spielberg, as with his last two films, doesn't really know when to end the film. Yet in general it leaves you with an unmistakable smile on your face throughout.Not to be missed!

reviewText: The Terminal is a real surprise.  Directed by Steven Spielberg and staring Tom Hanks (Saving Private Ryan, Catch Me if You Can).  The charming romantic comedy is one of the rare romantic comedies that actually is both romantic AND funny.  The Terminal truly does makes ones emotions come out.  You'll feel joy and sadness all at once as well as being moved by the performances!Viktor Navorski (Hanks) is a man who has come from Krakozia (a fictional country) to fulfill something for his father.  But as he made his way to America a millitary coup breaks out in his country and the government is overthrown.  Therefore, Krakozia is no longer recognized as a country by the rest of the world.  Victor can't go into America because his country is no longer recognized but he can't go back either because he also "has no country" and his passport becomes invalid.  So what does he do? He lives in The Terminal.Victor doesn't speak very good English and understand few words.  When he first arrives in the Terminal he's quite the outcast that can't do much for himself.  He's given food vouchers which, as you can imagine, he promptly loses.But overtime Victor gets friends in the Terminal.  He gets to know the Janitor and the one in charge of checking bags as well as a man who is willing to give him food if Victor delivers messages to the girl he likes.It's easy to see where the film begins to flaw.  Some of the things we see Victor do are useless to the film.  It's clear that Victor is doing what we're all doing when waiting for a flight, killing time.Then there's Amelie the stewartess (Catherine-Zeta Jones) and his love interest.  Their first meeting is a short meeting that comes about by accident.  Still, as the movie goes on they grow to like one another and Victor's friends even help him get a date.The movie presents great comedy and joy.  It's a fun-filled movie and the ending isn't what anyone expected from it.The Terminal is a feel good film but its long.  As I said, its clear that Victor is only killing time throughout his stay in The Terminal.The movie is great joy and humor and while its different from what we've usually seen from Spielberg and Hanks it is well acted and given the chemistry it needs to be a fantastic film!

reviewText: This film started out with some potential but ended on mediocrity. I think the film was lost somewhere in all the feel good moments and overly dramatic cheesiness. The film was loosely based on the true story of a man who was forced to live in the Charles de Gaulle International airport in Paris.The story starts out with Victor Navorsky (Tom Hanks) being denied access onto US soil after landing in NY from Krakozhia (a made up country for the story). Krakozhia essentially does not exist any more as it has fallen into a coup, therefore his passport and visa are rendered useless. The whole story is essentially Victor's day to day struggle to survive in this airport. Basically, the story starts to fall apart as soon as the original plot of him surviving wears off and it starts to delve more into the romantic comedy subplots.Hanks character was actually very well played and interesting to watch. It was intriguing watching him come up with ingenious ideas for making money to feed himself and different ways to make himself comfortable. Then there is the mystery of the can of peanuts throughout the whole movie which you only find out at the very end what its contents are.It's the other characters that draw life from the movie in my opinion. Tucci plays Dixon, the airport security guy who has made it his life mission to make Victor's life a living hell. His character was too one dimensional. He was too much the typical villain.Then there was Catherine Zita-Jones character. She played a flight attendant who was `the other woman' in a love triangle with a married man. Her character was an egotistical, weak minded woman who couldn't seem to break away (or just didn't want to break away) from her destructive situations. Again, her character was very one dimensional and the only reason I could see Hanks character having any interest in her would be completely sexual; which doesn't make for a very good plot for a movie that comes across as a romantic comedy. There needed to be more there; more feeling for their relationship. I felt nothing for the two of them. Also, I don't think Hanks and Zeta-Jones have very good chemistry on screen. Hanks and Meg Ryan have wonderful chemistry for example. Zeta-Jones just didn't cut it.Then there were the subplots of other airport workers that just came off as WAY over the top for me. For example, there was the romance between the INS agent and the food driver. Come on now!! Who in their right mind would get married to a man so introverted and shy he can't even propose to you himself. Also, why would you accept the ring after not even seeing the guy or knowing what he's like. Completely unrealistic and too mushy. Then the Indian janitor jumping in front of the airplane. It's these kinds of things in the film that just come across as forced and annoying.I actually didn't notice it was a Spielberg film until the end credits and I was absolutely shocked. I have liked a lot of Spielberg's films and I have a great respect for him, but this was way below standards. Maybe he should just steer away from trying to make cutesy, romantic comedies.

reviewText: The Terminal is an ordinary little movie that looks a heck of a lot like a TV sitcom. With Steven Spielberg and Tom Hanks in charge, I expected much more entertainment.The plot is weak and silly beyond the basic premise of a man getting trapped by bureaucratic red tape and having to live inside the airport until his immigration status gets worked out. OK, I can accept that, but the main characters feel like they do various actions only because the script says to, not because it fits into their characters. Catherine Zeta-Jones looks fantastic, but plays a person who is very messed up at relationships on the inside. Her attraction to Hanks' character is not believable, nor is his to her. Tom plays a Jimmy Stewart type guy, so why would he be attracted to a stewardess who has affairs with married men and can't let go?Stanley Tucci plays a realistic airport security manager who has a few scenes to show he is really good at his job and a decent guy. However, to put some tension in the story he does some out-of-the-blue mean spirited things to make Hanks' life a little tougher to bump the story along. For all the money and talent that had to be available to pull this movie together, it just seems like a weak script.There are the typical ethnic sidekicks to the Tom Hanks character who strain to provide the standard initial comic relief, then enable the hero to reach his impossible goal, in this case the predictable Lady and the Tramp dinner with C Z-J in a romantic and out of the way part of JFK airport Right!One of these guys is an odd Indian janitor who ran away from India years before to escape arrest for knifing a cop, who takes delight in watching airport patrons slip and fall on his freshly mopped floors. He is paranoid and rude to the people he encounters, yet we are supposed to find him a sympathetic character because the script says he is. He seems more like a psychotic on the lam rather than a lovable eccentric from TV land. It just does not click very smoothly.The dialog is a little stale and clichéd, again sounding like a TV show, not a movie from the big guys. They also ran out of things to do to move the story along so they repeated the same things again. An example that comes to mind is the cracker and condiment supper that happens twice. The first time it was kind of a mild "oh, gross!" moment, but the second it stuck out as unnecessary and redundant. Again I found myself watching and wondering why the script was so thin.By the time Spielberg's name scrolls out in the credits in cursive the show felt contrived and long. This is not a poorly made movie, but a poorly designed one. Bottom line, this is a renter at best.

reviewText: Steven Spielberg's "The Terminal" is a surprisingly underwhelming effort from the master filmmaker.  It appeared to have all the ingredients needed to be a winner but it ended up just being a confused mess of cliches and loose ends.Krakozia citizen Viktor Navorski (Tom Hanks) flies in to the United States and is detained as soon as he lands.  It turns out his visa has been cancelled because there has been a military coup in his homeland.  Viktor therefore cannot lawfully enter the country.  Further complicating matters is that he cannot be deported home either because the United States is not recognizing the newly installed Krakozia government.  Due to this strange set of circumstances, Viktor finds himself trapped at the airport terminal until the situation is resolved.  To pass the time, he befriends the colorful airport employees around him and tries to gain the attention of the beautiful Amelia Warren (Catherine Zeta-Jones), a flight attendant who frequently passes through his area.One cannot shake the feeling that "The Terminal" is unfinished.  Spielberg and Hanks do a great job of setting up Viktor's plight but after establishing his resourcefulness, the film disintegrates into a hodgepodge of subplots that only detract from the main story.  We just keep getting one dilemma after another that feel more at home on a television situation-comedy.  Also, when the reason for Viktor's journey to America is revealed, it just feels like an afterthought and is completely absent of any emotional resonance.  Hanks turns in a wonderful and charming performance and Zeta-Jones is radiant is her underdeveloped role.  Yet, the top-notch acting does not salvage "The Terminal."  This is one film that should have been grounded until all the problems with the script were sorted out.

reviewText: Loosely based on the true and ongoing story of the man that is living at the French airport, The Terminal takes the concept and runs with it to turn this into the "feel-good" movie of the year. Is it the best effort by Speilberg or Hanks? Not by a long shot. Is it somewhat predictable in parts? Absolutely.Viktor (Hanks), gets hung up in a ball of red tape when his homeland is pitched into a revolution at some point during his flight, leaving him without a valid Visa as his country is not officially recognized by the US or the UN during the coup.  So, he is not allowed to enter the US, and airport security has little choice but to leave him in the terminal at JFK airport.While stuck, Viktor learns to make the most of his situation, makes friends with the employees, and falls for a love troubled flight attendant played by Catherine Zeta-Jones.Without giving a whole lot more away, I will say that the romance is not the most believable I have seen on the screen. You just don't see hot stewardesses involving themselves with earnest foreign men, though you can accept it when you realize that yes, people will only see what it is they want to see when they are idealizing anyone, and Jones' Amelia is the type of woman that idealizes people, which is probably why she has been involved with a married man for nearly a decade. The rest of the supporting cast is pretty fun to watch, and Hanks' adventures in the airport run the gamut of emotion.Though fairly predictable and at times hard to swallow, this movie is well worth the watch, and I would watch it again given the chance. Again, not the greatest effort on the parts of either Speilberg or Hanks, but considering their greatest efforts have given us some of the best cinema in the past 15 years, it isn't necessarily a bad thing when I say that.
