reviewText: "The Terminal" wasn't exactly a "must-see" on my list when it first came out, but I ended up watching it when it came on cable recently. I don't see the need to mention what the plot of the film is since so many others before me have already done so quite well. While I really liked the sentimental purpose behind Viktor Navorsky's (played excellently by Tom Hanks) Christmastime visit to the United States, "The Terminal" drags along in an attempt to make an interesting light-hearted romantic comedy out of something that was loosely based on an actual event. This idea might have worked, given the right script. But this script was far from being the right one because it is very uneven, insipid and unconvincing.For example: Viktor understands absolutely NO ENGLISH when he initially arrives in the U.S. They aren't able to find him a translator at all during the course of the film??  How is it that he is able to learn how to pronounce words and educate himself well enough virtually overnight by comparing an English version of a book to one that he has in his language? Yet, as the film progresses, he STILL doesn't understand that the terminal director (Stanley Tucci) is giving him permission to leave, so he stays?Next: Viktor living in a section of the airport that is closed to the public and under renovation...where is the SECURITY guarding such a place in an international airport (this is supposed to be set in John F. Kennedy International Airport in Queens, NY), post-9/11 world?! For all they know, the guy could be a freaking terrorist.Then this: Him doing unauthorized contracting jobs without ever being questioned about it. And on top of that, he is able to land a job, being paid very well under the table by the contractors that are working in the airport. Hmmm.And this: The shy food handler (Diego Luna) that Viktor helps win the heart of the customs agent (Zoe Saldana) who never even seemed to notice him, and incidentally, this same customs agent shares information about her personal life with Viktor, a complete stranger (???)And this, too: Amelia (Catherine Zeta-Jones) the flight attendant that Viktor is attracted to, who is having an affair with a married man, being so scatter-brained that she doesn't know which way is up. Hanks and Zeta-Jones have no on-screen chemistry AT ALL, either.And yet another one: The scene when Viktor is finally leaving the airport surrounded by all the friends he's made reminds you of something out of "It's a Wonderful Life" and many other silly scenarios in the movie other than the ones I mentioned are straight out of the old Hollywood book of schlocky, somewhat happy endings.What was really frustrating about this movie (other than the length - it was about an hour and a half too long) was the way the "relationship" between Viktor and Amelia should have progressed, but didn't. The way things ended with them was too abrupt and didn't make sense. Seems like the writers concentrated so much on the things that Viktor was doing as a resident of the terminal throughout the film, they didn't know exactly how to resolve the Amelia situation, so they threw a cheesy and unsatisfying ending together. Bad idea. They would have done better to eliminate her character from the script altogether, since she really had no effect on the outcome of the movie."The Terminal" is far from being the worst movie ever made. But there are too many sub-plots in this film, and the trouble is that Spielberg tries to cram them all in, therefore making it way too long. I couldn't imagine having to go see this in the theaters, because I'm sure I would have either swirmed all the way through it or gotten up and walked out. I kept waiting for something interesting to happen, but it just never did. Two and a half stars for the cast, which was unfortunately wasted here, and that's about it.

reviewText: The Terminal is an excellent comedy/drama that teams Tom Hanks and Steven Spielberg together once again.  While it not may be their best work together, The Terminal stands far above most of the movies released this year.  Viktor Navorski is flying to JFK Airport in New York when his home country, Krakozhia, is overthrown during a military coup.  Because of this, Navorski's passport, visa, and ticket are invalidated, meaning he can't go back home, and he can't go to the U.S.  The only option left is to stay in the international terminal of the airport.  Making the best of the situation, Viktor begins to learn English, learn the ways of the airport, and even get a job as a contractor with a group renovating parts of the airport.  Most importantly, Viktor begins to make an impact on the airport staff.  Meanwhile, the airport security director is trying to find a way to get Viktor out of his hair and out of the airport.  This is a very good, heartfelt movie.  And while it may not be Spielberg's best, it is still well worth a watch.Tom Hanks give an excellent performance as Viktor Navorski, a native of Krakozhia forced to live in JFK airport.  Like most of the characters he plays, Hanks' Viktor is incredibly likable.  Catherine Zeta-Jones plays Amelia Warren, a stewardess who befriends Viktor.  Stanley Tucci plays Frank Dixon, the airport chief of security who wants the popular Viktor out of his terminal.  Chi McBride, Diego Luna, and Kumar Pallana are excellent in supporting roles as airport staff that become Viktor's friends during his stay in the airport.  If you buy the DVD, beware because there are two different widescreen copies available.  One offers just the movie while the other offers widescreen presentation and plenty of great extras including interviews with Hanks and Spielberg.  I recommend the one with extras for a deeper look at the movie.  For an excellent, heartfelt movie from Tom Hanks and Steven Spielberg, check out The Terminal!
summary: Hanks and Spielberg do it again

reviewText: I'm a sucker for airports and airport movies. There's something about the mixture of giant architecture and masses of strangers either in constant motion or enforced inertia that implies that anything can happen. All human emotion is there - joy, hope, sorrow, anger - frustrations mix with small triumphs and plans are alternately thwarted or triumph. Therefore 'The Terminal' was a real surprise - an almost total misfire from Steven Spielberg that fails to work on almost every level.Spielberg has never made a really bad film before (even his weaker efforts have had something going for them), but he's finally pulled it off here. So much is so wrong about this film it's hard to know where to start. The script is a major offender, trite and ineffectual at every turn and so desperate to reaffirm belief in America post 9/11 as a land of such open heart and infinite wonders, populated entirely by nice people that you really can't understand why anyone would possibly want to leave the airport it's just so gosh darned nice. Rather than an impersonal prison merely impersonating life, the airport becomes a playground where magical things happen if you only look. It's so resolutely upbeat and unreal, it's depressing. Worse, it quickly becomes apparent that Spielberg has no real feel for his location: it's just a giant set that never once convinces for all it's detail.Speilberg's direction is surprisingly poor. He always had the ability to convey fear and confusion - think E.T. lost in the woods or Jim wandering through the chaotic streets of Shanghai as the Japanese overrun the city - but he's completely lost that in the opening scenes. Instead of panic and alienation we get a very flat succession of shots that end up in a technically impressive crane shot revealing the entire set but which leaves us feeling nothing, let alone identifying with the hero. Part of this is admittedly due to the fact that Hanks' performance starts out both terrible AND insulting - hey, those crazy East Europeans aren't just stupid children, they can't even walk properly: they waddle like clockwork toy ducks! - but that does at least improve as the film continues.The supporting cast are equally unbelievable despite the cast's best efforts. Is it really credible that two airport workers would actually marry without ever having even met, let alone been on a date on the strength of Viktor's skills as a romantic go-between? (Considering how nauseatingly phoney the scene where she reveals the engagement ring is, perhaps it would have been better if they had never met.) Even the obstreperous janitor who loves to watch passengers slip up on his floor turns out to be a loveable cop-killer with great juggling skills (no really) who spreads the legend of Viktor's great deeds in the single worst-staged scenes in Spielberg's entire career.Strangely enough, the only one who really shines here is Catherine Zeta Jones, an extremely limited and somewhat self-important screen presence in most films but who somehow manages to be refreshingly believable despite being saddled with some truly terrible dialog (her `like' story with Hanks is peppered with inane references to Napoleon and Josephine). The resolution to their relationship is the film's one surprise.Worse is to come in the tacked on finale. Endings are always Spielberg's Achilles heel, but this one is just an insult. For no rational reason whatsoever, Stanley Tucci's character acts in an unnecessarily malicious way simply to provide some sense of dramatic tension. Naturally, it fails miserably because we know everyone in the airport loves Viktor too much to go through with Tucci's moustache-twirling dastardliness (ok, he has no moustache, but that's merely an oversight).A blandly impressive package of extras (that scrupulously ignore the much more tragic true story that inspired it) are included.
summary: One of Spielberg's few real failures

So, he ends up living in the airport terminal, befriending the staff and becoming somewhat of a local celebrity.The movie is full of comical moments. However, it also has its serious side. The acting in the film is top notch, especially by the supporting cast, as is Spielberg's direction (we wouldn't expect anything less). There are a few corny lines of dialogue here and there, but overall the script is good. Catherine Zeta-Jones' clumsy stewardess character comes off as annoying at times, but doesn't distract from the overall theme of the movie.THE TERMINAL is comical, somewhat romantic, and even dramatic at times. It delves into how people build relationships with each other and slightly pokes fun of our mass consumer culture. However, the heart and soul of the movie has very little to do with those things. THE TERMINAL is one of the best movies to ever be made about how to live a life of honor. Viktor is a man who lives a life of honor. He lives by his Trouthe--when he gives his word he means it; his word is his bond. There was a time not so long ago when people would say something, they would mean it--if a person made a promise, they kept it. We've lost that virtue and there aren't very many people who are truly living an honorable life. THE TERMINAL illustrates how a person can live a life of honor and why that life if so much more rewarding than one built upon broken promises and useless words.

reviewText: I heard one critic say that this film was basically Cast Away in an airport and I have to say that I think he/she is right. reviewText: The umbrella of "the terminal" gets in the way of some of the best parts of this movie. First of all, of course, the concept that someone could be stuck in a terminal for months, working as a carpenter, setting up a bachelor pad at Gate 67, etc. etc., is ludicrous. But let's suspend disbelief. Even if you buy the premise, it still gets in the way of the movie's success.It seems that Spielberg wanted to cram as many subplots as possible under this umbrella, but a couple of them are much more compelling than the others -- namely, the love plot between Enrique Cruz (Diego Luna) and Officer Torres (Zoe Saldana) which Viktor Navorski (Tom Hanks) sweetly facilitiates, and Viktor's rescue of a Russian compatriot from the grips of the evil Frank Dixon's (Stanley Tucci's) grasp as he attempt to carry life-saving medicine from Canada back to his father in the homeland. The rest of the film is a falling off.If only Spielberg had known where to stop. But of course, there has to be the obligatory romance between Viktor and the ingenue Amelia Warren (the gorgeous Catherine Zeta-Jones) -- which, again of course, cannot work out or how could the movie end? And all the silly by-play with the talented Kumar Pallana! Without spoiling the film, all I can say is that the ultimate fate reserved for this character violates the entire comic spirit of this movie.Hanks is charming as ever, and the rest of the cast does their part. But the film finally topples over under the weight of its own absurd premise.

reviewText: The Terminal, in a word, is alright. It was funny throughout most of the running time. In fact, there were a few big laughs. But on a scale of 1 to 10, the film was a 6. I say this because, besides the premise, there was nothing that original.The love story at its core is conventional. And at the end, Catherine Zeta-Jones' character seems to be more of a plot device than an actual person (the final look makes you go, "I get it, but...why?"). I did like Tom Hanks. He made you want to love his character. The rest of the cast is basically good. Stanly Tucci --who Oscar-watchers predicted would be nominated-- is, unfortunately, a one-note character with an inexplicable, slight revelation towards the end. I give Tucci credit for understanding how unreasonably annoying and cruel his character is.The story is touching, to an extent. This is probably director Steven Speilberg's sappiest film I've ever seen. However, there are problems with the plot, thanks to uneven writing. And unfortunately, despite being based on a true story, it seems to have no purpose other than to entertain the masses, which isn't all bad, of course. But as far as being well-made, well...it's just not. I blame that on Speilberg. I think he could have made better choices for time. He could have cut things out, made the film shorter and more beleivable (which it wasn't, by the way). I'm beginning to think that he felt he was making a masterpiece when what he was given didn't have the potential to be more than pure entertainment. If my theory happens to be true, then I can see why some things were left in. He wanted to send a messege about...well, I'm not too sure what he was trying to say. But whatever it was, it wasn't conveyed well.Despite all this, there were upsides. As I had previously mentioned, Tom Hanks was great, there were many laughs, a few of them large. But what stands out is the production design. It's fantastic, I mean it just drew me in completely. And I was shocked to hear that it was so realistic that those who worked on the film during shooting persuaded someone to allow the merchandise to be for sale. Apparently, people shopped in there, despite the terminal being no more than a set built in two very large hangers. You'll have to see the film for yourself. It's truly breath-taking. I don't think Roger Ebert is right in saying, "Whoever designed these sets will surely win the Oscar," because AMPAS doesn't seem to give the Art/Set Design award to films that aren't period or epics set in the past. But if I ran the Oscars, I would most definitely award the Terminal for its outstanding acheivement in production design.So I recommend The Terminal to those of you who are looking for basic entertainment with slight --very slight-- flare. I have to admit, it did make me smile. Movies don't necessarily have to be well-made to be entertaining.

reviewText: The set-up for "The Terminal" intrigues all who hear it:  An Eastern European flies to America, only to have the government of his country overthrown during the flight, thus voided the validity of his passport and stranded him in the airport until the US government can decide what to do with him.  To this fascinating plotline, add Tom Hanks as the lead role and Steven Spielberg as the man behind the camera, and the recipe exists for a magical film, right?  Well...not exactly.The architects of the film do not trust the story to carry it.  They add many manufactured and tired conflicts to drag the audience along while they wait to see the fate of Hanks' Viktor.  Even though his predicament establishes an unforgettable quandary to build a film around, Spielberg felt the need to create an antagonist whose motivations to harm Hanks really can't be explained.  Viewers will understand why the head of the airport (Stanley Tucci) wants to follow all rules concerning his new stranded guest, but once he becomes obsessed with Viktor and tries to sabotage his plans for survival, his actions can't be realistically explained.  Spielberg commits one of the most common faults of writers/directors: he builds a character who works more as a agent of the plot than as someone to help tell the story naturally.The movie is not a total disaster.  Many laugh out loud moments are found among this most unique of comic situations.  Some of the resourceful and creative ways the isolated immigrant survives in the airport will remind many of Hanks in "Castaway".  At times, the heavily populated terminal presents a more desolate environment than the abandoned island Hanks inhabited in that film (at least there he always had his volleyball).Hanks and Spielberg continue their trend of making films that speak to issues of importance.  While Viktor's introduction to America is not the common experience of immigrants, he works as a metaphor for the ills of the endless and illogical bureaucracy awaiting the "tired, poor, huddled masses" coming to the USA.
summary: Doesn't meet expectations set for Hanks and Spielberg
